SUMMARY: Galactose repressor, GalR, is a DNA-binding transcription factor that represses transcription of operons involved in transport and catabolism of D-galactose [17630975, 7934815, 8416900, 8982002]. Synsis of se operons is induced when E. coli is grown in presence of inducer (D-galactose) and absence glucose [8982002, 7934815, 1619663, 8416900]. expression of galR is increased only in presence of inducer [8416900, 8982002]. In particular, in absence of D-galactose, GalR represses galETKM operon[9218807]. In this repression system, GalR binds to two operators in presence of HU, resulting in formation of a repressor loop [9218807, 12169637, 15289461]. This repressor binds in tandem to inverted repeat sequences that are 16 nucleotides long and possess conserved motifs; each dimer binds to one of se conserved sequences [7934815, 8416900]. On or hand, GalR is highly homologous in its amino acid sequence to GalS (55% identical and 88% similar); apparently both act toger and are capable of cross-talk to regulate expression of gal regulon [1619663, 8982002]. For this reason se regulators bind same operators, in cis regulatory regions, with different affinities [8175668]. In presence of inductor, GalR undergoes a conformational change that reduces its affinity for operator. Golding et al. showed that GalR is major repressor of gal operon [1655705]. GalR belongs to GalR/LacI family of transcriptional regulators. Accordingly, this transcriptional repressor family protein is composed of two domains: a conserved N-terminal domain which contains DNA-binding region, and carboxy-terminal domain, which is involved in effector binding and dimerization [1619663, 8982002]. GalR and GalS have only two substitutions in first helix of N-terminal domain [1619663].
